;;T;<小>;HE VIDEO;弗朗西斯斯科特基大桥倒塌的镜头令人震惊。 3月26日凌晨1时30分左右，一艘集装箱船撞上它，这座1.6英里（2.6公里）长的建筑的中心部分塌陷到下面的帕塔普斯科河中，导致人员和车辆落入水中。当时，桥上正在修复坑洼的工人。水下无人机、声纳和红外工具显示多辆车辆淹没在河中。 “你永远不会想到你会看到......基桥像那样倒塌，”巴尔的摩市长布兰登·斯科特告诉记者。 “它看起来像是动作片中的东西。”

;; ;

;马里兰州州长宣布进入紧急状态。截至周二晚上，潜水员正在搜寻六人。美国土木工程师学会结构工程研究所 (ASCE) 主席杰里·哈贾 (Jerry Hajjar) 表示，除了人员伤亡之外，迫在眉睫的问题还涉及这场灾难的原因和后果，这是美国几十年来最严重的灾难之一。 ;）。 ;FBI; 表示恐怖主义不太可能是幕后黑手。

;

;这艘 300 米长的船根据网络安全和基础设施安全局的一份非机密报告，;Dali; 号正从巴尔的摩港前往斯里兰卡科伦坡，当时“失去了推进力”。据报道，船员通知官员可能会发生桥梁碰撞。目击者称，船的灯光在撞击前闪烁。当地人在半夜听到了雷鸣般的隆隆声。 “房子开始摇晃，”海港对面的马里兰州 Locust Point 居民赛勒斯·吉尔伯特 (Cyrus Gilbert) 说道。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;这座桥的结构本来应该是健全的。 ;ASCE; 的一份报告在 2020 年为马里兰州的桥梁授予了 ;B; 评级，并为港口授予了 ;B-; 评级。邓迪大学科学与工程学院土木工程和造船建筑专家 Masoud Hayatdavoodi 说： “毫无疑问，桥梁会因柱子受到冲击而倒塌。”

;

;乔·拜登总统承诺将为此买单尽快重建桥梁。但对这座城市的经济影响已经显现。港口交通已关闭，直至另行通知，这在港口以外引起了涟漪。该港口支持超过 15,000 个直接就业岗位，并且大约有 140,000 个就业岗位以某种方式与之相关。这包括从亚马逊司机到当地干洗店的一切。该港口不仅在巴尔的摩，而且在马里兰州都有着巨大的足迹。马里兰州陶森大学区域经济研究所的达里斯·伊拉尼 (Dariys Irani) 表示，仅港口关闭一项就可能造成每天约 50 美元的经济活动损失。

;

;清理期间，端口活动可能会减慢或暂停。该港口是美国供应链的重要一环。超过 50 家海运承运人每年进行近 1,800 次访问。这在汽车领域尤其重要。 2023 年，其私人和公共码头处理了近 85 万辆汽车和轻型卡车，是美国港口中处理量最多的。 2023年，该港口在农业和建筑机械以及进口糖和石膏的吞吐量方面也排名全国第一，煤炭出口排名全国第二。

;

;如果另一个港口因某种原因（例如，由于天气、劳资纠纷或网络攻击）出现问题，美国经济可能会遭受严重损失。但就目前而言，全国影响可能有限。其他港口，如纽约-新泽西和弗吉尼亚港口，应该能够弥补这一空缺。评级机构穆迪首席经济学家马克赞迪表示，国民经济将<小>;好;，但巴尔的摩将感受到集体钱包的痛苦。通勤者和卡车司机也将面临干扰。去年，该桥每天为 34,000 辆商业和客运车辆提供服务，约占该地区交通量的 15%。

;

;巴尔的摩港长期以来一直是美国韧性的象征。 1812 年抗英战争期间，美国人成功保卫了巴尔的摩港的麦克亨利堡，弗朗西斯·斯科特·基 (Francis Scott Key) 在他的 19 世纪诗歌中将这一事件永垂不朽，该诗后来成为美国国歌。这场悲剧将使城市和港口有时间实施升级，而当港口活跃时，这会变得更加困难。在了解了灾难的全部范围并适当哀悼逝去的生命后，巴尔的摩可能会出现更好的桥梁和港口。 ;■;

;;;;在呼吁中国;时，西方政府有时喜欢站在一起。 3月25日至26日，美国、英国和新西兰联合打击中国网络间谍活动。美国检察官指责中国的网络间谍多年来针对西方的广泛目标发动了一场行动，其中包括批评中国共产党的人。英国副首相奥利弗·道登表示，中国表现出“针对我们集体民主国家的持续敌对活动模式”。新西兰指责中国与国家有关的黑客对该国议会发起网络攻击。

;

;美国和英国都对涉嫌的中国黑客实施了制裁一组中国黑客的幌子公司，他们称之为 ;APT;31。他们还对该组织的两名涉嫌成员实施了制裁，而美国则对他们和另外五名男子提出了刑事指控。这些行动不太可能对中国的努力产生太大影响。字母;APT;代表“高级持续威胁”。这是涉及潜伏在目标网络中未被发现的攻击的技术术语。这些话也恰好传达了西方对中国网络攻击的悲观看法。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;发现网络入侵（更不用说确定责任人）可能需要时间。西方三个国家揭露的事件大多发生在两三年前。道登先生告​​诉议会，“中国政府附属行为者”已于 2021 年侵入了选举委员会的电子邮件和文件共享系统。这一违规行为于 2023 年 8 月首次公开宣布，当时官员透露，直到 2022 年 10 月才发现可疑活动——黑客入侵一年多后。肇事者可以访问英国选民的地址。道登没有具体说明参与此次袭击的组织。但他表示，;APT;31 “几乎可以肯定”是 2021 年针对 ;MP; 电子邮件帐户的“侦察活动”的幕后黑手。其中大多数目标都是著名的批评者中国。

;

;向纽约法院提交的针对 ;APT;31 七名成员的起诉书提供了丰富的细节该团队的活动。这份长达 27 页的文件称，该组织隶属于中国主要间谍机构——国家安全部 (;MSS;) 湖北省分局。其幌子公司武汉晓睿智科技有限公司Technology 成立于 2010 年左右。据称，从那时起，该组织就针对美国和其他地方的数千名政客、学者、记者和民主活动人士。根据该文件，它还针对被视为“国家重要性”的美国行业的个人和公司，包括与国防、<小>;IT;和电信相关的行业。

;

;英国淡化了其发现的中国黑客攻击的影响——没有选举受到影响，并且;议员;的电子邮件的目标是“被议会的网络安全措施阻止”。新西兰表示，另一个与 ;MSS; 相关的组织，名为 ;APT;40，参与了 2021 年针对其议会的网络攻击，但这并未导致信息泄露敏感信息。然而，美国起诉书称，;APT;31 的活动“已导致数百万美国人的工作和个人电子邮件帐户、云存储帐户和电话记录遭到确认和潜在的泄露，其中至少包括可能会发布一些信息来支持针对民主进程和机构的恶意影响”。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;网络安全公司 Recorded Future 的 Mark Kelly 表示，他的公司据了解，中国有大约 50 个黑客组织，其中包括为 ;MSS; 或中国人民解放军工作的私营公司。毫无疑问还有更多。凯利先生将中国的网络间谍活动描述为“数量级”，其规模比俄罗斯或朝鲜的网络间谍活动还要大。

;

;起诉书显示，他们的权力下放令人惊讶。英国情报机构军情六处前副局长奈杰尔·英克斯特 (Nigel Inkster) 表示，其中一些人专门从事世界不同地区的间谍活动。他说，他们有相当大的余地可以按照自己的意愿行事：“我什至不确定是否存在任何正式的政治许可机制。”他们的大部分工作都分包给私营公司。上个月，I-Soon 等公司的大量在线文件显示该公司代表多个政府机构参与了大规模网络窥探活动。

;

;西方的焦虑越来越明显。一月份，<小>;联邦调查局;负责人克里斯托弗·雷 (Christopher Wray) 声称，中国政府支持的黑客数量与联邦调查局网络人员的数量“至少为 50 比 1”。他表示，中国的目标不仅是政治和军事：“中国的黑客正在美国的基础设施上进行部署，准备在中国决定发动攻击的时候对美国公民和社区造成严重破坏并造成现实伤害。”< /p>;

;中国外交官驳回了此类指控。中国驻伦敦大使馆发言人称英国的指控是“捏造和恶意诽谤”。如果西方希望通过点名、羞辱和制裁来劝阻中国间谍，那么它很可能会失望。正如英克斯特先生所说：“我认为北京不再特别担心手指伸进收银台会带来的政治后果。” ;■;

;;A; ;十年前; 习近平在德国杜伊斯堡受到欢迎鲁尔河谷。他称赞该地区是中国投资的中心；迎接一列从重庆出发，经俄罗斯，前往欧洲工业带，用了两周时间的列车；并欣赏了传统采矿歌曲的管弦乐演奏。最近，另一位中国人抵达德国却受到冷遇。今年 2 月，一艘名为“比亚迪探索者号 1 号”的船卸下了约 3,000 辆由中国电动汽车 (;EV;) 公司 ;BYD; 制造的电动汽车。正如这艘船的名字所暗示的，它很可能是众多船舶中的第一艘。毫不奇怪，它引发了人们对德国神圣汽车制造商未来的担忧。

;

;中国正在大量生产汽车，其领导人将现金和贷款输送到高科技产业，试图重振该国垂死的经济。其制造业贸易顺差已创历史新高，并且还将继续上升。因此，欧洲领导人担心先进、廉价的中国商品涌入。 3 月 5 日，欧盟委员会决定有足够证据宣布中国对其<小>;电动汽车;制造商提供不公平补贴，为征收关税铺平了道路。该委员会主席乌苏拉·冯德莱恩(Ursula von der Leyen)警告中国不要在绿色科技方面“竞相抄底”。英国已开始对该国的挖掘机进行调查。法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙将于五月接待习近平。据外交官称，他将在贸易问题上传递“坚定的信息”。

;;
;;
;

;从巴西到印度的国家正在采取行动阻止中国的出口。然而，由于欧洲大陆长期以来以贸易为核心的增长模式，它们对欧洲构成了特殊的威胁。据;国际货币基金组织;称，欧洲是世界上贸易和投资最开放的地区（见图1）。在;欧盟;，商品和服务贸易占;GDP;的44%，几乎是美国的两倍。作为一个以规则为基础的集团，欧盟不愿通过设置保护主义壁垒来公然违反贸易规则。英国也是如此，历来支持自由贸易。

;

;新的中国冲击来得正是时候。欧洲工业仍在应对弗拉基米尔·普京入侵乌克兰造成的能源冲击，这次入侵正值各国领导人试图加速绿色转型之际开始。天然气价格通常为每兆瓦时 20 欧元（22 美元）左右，到 2022 年将飙升至 300 欧元以上，导致电价飙升（见图 2）。新冠疫情后的反弹演变成通货膨胀和能源危机。欧洲央行 (;ECB;) 被迫将利率提高至 4%，打击了本已疲软的经济的需求。

;
;;
;

;疫情和能源危机期间的财政慷慨已被紧缩所取代。德国严格的赤字限制迫使该国今年削减开支，2025 年还将进一步削减。法国刚刚宣布 2023 年赤字占 GDP 的 5.5%，远高于预期。它已经取消了财政部长布鲁诺·勒梅尔所说的“紧急刹车”，削减了 100 亿欧元的支出，以使财政政策重回正轨。

;
; ;
;

;;欧盟;的 <自 2019 年以来，GDP 实际增长率仅为 4%，仅为美国增速的一半。在英国和德国，人均GDP实际上已经下降（见图3）。官方预测欧盟和英国今年的经济增长率将低于 1%；除此之外，事情还不确定。尽管美国的生产力在疫情期间似乎再次得到提振，但欧洲的生产力却步履维艰。 ;欧洲央行;、各国领导人、智囊团以及意大利两位前总理恩里科·莱塔和马里奥·德拉吉正在试图找出欧洲究竟为何失去“竞争力”的原因。与此同时，另一个威胁迫在眉睫：如果唐纳德·特朗普赢得 11 月份的美国总统大选，欧洲出口商可能会在向其利润最丰厚的市场之一销售产品时被征收关税。

;;

;震撼恐怖

;

;因此，随着非洲大陆经济因 2022 年俄罗斯的冲击而陷入困境，它将如何适应来自中国的新冲击，或许还有来自美国的三分之一？中国的第一次冲击发生在2001年，当时中国加入了世界贸易组织，并因此受益于较低的贸易壁垒，对西方制造商构成了挑战。在美国，一些地区和行业受到重创。欧洲的表现较为轻松，部分原因是此次冲击恰逢中欧和东欧国家加入<小>;欧盟;。 ;欧盟;最新成员国的快速发展支持了该集团的生产力增长并创造了对西方商品的需求。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;这次会有所不同。尽管为了应对经济困境，中国正在转向高科技制造业，但习近平也热衷于让中国摆脱对西方工业的依赖。他希望在工业机器人和铁路设备等他认为对国家实力至关重要的领域建立技术领先地位。一个旨在减少对外国投入依赖的较弱的中国将购买更少的汽车、机械和高科技设备，而这些正是在第一次中国冲击期间提振欧洲出口的商品。中国的经济规模也比世纪之交时要大得多。正如咨询公司 Absolute Strategy 的 Adam Wolfe 指出的那样，自 2019 年以来中国出口的增长（占该国;GDP;的比例不大）在其他地方已经感觉像是洪水泛滥。

;

;此外，欧洲公司现在在国内和第三国日益复杂的市场中面临着中国的竞争。以欧洲工业皇冠上的明珠汽车为例。该行业及其供应链在整个非洲大陆雇用了约 300 万人。然而，根据汽车顾问马蒂亚斯·施密特的数据，中国品牌已经占据西欧纯电池市场 9% 的份额。在整个非洲大陆，2022 年至 2023 年间，中国品牌消费汽车的新注册量增加了一倍多。法国、德国和意大利的大众市场品牌似乎特别容易受到竞争的影响。 ;UBS; 银行的分析师估计，到 2030 年，“传统”汽车制造商的全球市场份额将从目前的 81% 下降到 58%。

;

;欧洲领导人特别热衷于发展绿色产业，为气候转型投入了数十亿美元。然而，为大众市场生产的欧洲公司将难以与中国竞争对手提供的价值竞争。例如，根据行业机构全球风能理事会的数据，中国已经在风力涡轮机领域占据主导地位，到 2022 年，中国的市场份额将达到 60%。这为其制造商提供了进一步创新所需的规模。而且事情只朝着一个方向发展。中国衡量出厂价格的生产者价格指数已连续 17 个月下降，大致处于 2019 年的水平。;欧盟;的相同指数，即使不包括能源成本，也为比四年前的水平高出近四分之一。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;欧洲自己试图从中国“降低风险”，即减少从中国采购关键投入并限制对其的投资和高科技产品的出口——也会推高成本。比勒费尔德大学的朱利安·欣茨（Julian Hinz）和合著者在最近的一篇论文中研究了与中国及其盟友硬脱钩的影响。对于与中国联系最紧密的欧洲经济体德国来说，他们发现逐步调整将花费;GDP;的1.2%，与日本大致相同。其他主要欧洲国家和美国将损失约0.5%的;GDP;。中国的损失将达到 2% 左右。

;

;如果特朗普在 11 月获胜，欧洲的去风险成本将变得更难以承受。新的关税对非洲大陆的出口商来说是一个严峻的前景，去年非洲大陆向美国出口了 5000 亿欧元的商品。事实上，;欧盟;的 27 个成员国中有 20 个与该国实现了货物贸易顺差。

;

;特朗普在第一个任期内加剧了紧张局势，当时美国对铝和钢铁征收高额关税，对欧洲生产商造成打击。作为回应，欧洲对美国产品征收关税，包括波本威士忌和摩托车。乔·拜登到来后，双方才达成（有些不稳定的）休战协议。特朗普2.0可能会更加痛苦。这位前总统提议对所有美国进口商品征收 10% 的关税。他的贸易顾问罗伯特·莱特希泽(Robert Lighthizer)走得更远，最近认为可能“有必要”征收更残酷的关税。

;

;莱特希泽的沉重打击

;

;智库德国经济研究所已经计算了可能的影响。想象一下，美国对其进口产品征收10%的关税，并以更高的关税惩罚中国。美国自身的经济将因消费价格上涨而受到打击，但欧洲的经济将受到更大的打击。到 2028 年，德国的出口总额将比美国没有新关税的世界低近 5%。私人投资也将受到打击。结果，德国 GDP 将下降 1.2%，相当于到 2028 年累计损失价值 1200 亿欧元。特朗普政府可能会走得更远，寻求对欧洲的数字服务进行报复针对美国科技公司的税收，或拒绝遵守总统对中国的路线。

;

;同时，当涉及到中国之间的紧张关系时而<小>;欧盟;、<小>; ;针对补贴和倾销的针锋相对的调查看起来可能会变得普遍。例如，中国政府很清楚谁是<小>;欧盟;<小>;电动汽车;调查的幕后黑手：它已对法国干邑白兰地启动了反倾销调查。法国为消费者设计了自己的;ev;补贴，将中国品牌排除在外；中国公司向客户提供同等幅度的回扣，一位分析师称之为“向马克龙先生伸出一根手指的问候”。

;

;能源、中国和特朗普冲击的结合可能会导致欧洲经济的长期重组。对于非洲大陆的消费者来说，这将是一件喜忧参半的事情。贸易战使商品价格上涨并减少选择，但当中国补贴太阳能电池板时，欧洲公用事业公司和家庭可以获得更便宜的能源。一些地区也可能受益。西班牙等拥有太阳能潜力的国家，或拥有水力和风能的瑞典等国家可以吸引新的产业。事实上，今年早些时候，瑞典公司 ;H;2 Green Steel 宣布已为其位于该国北部吕勒奥附近的工厂筹集了 65 亿欧元的资金。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;同样，当贸易困难时，一些外国公司会希望在欧洲投资以贴近客户。 2021 年和 2022 年，波兰吸引了近 300 亿欧元的外国直接投资 (;fdi;)，2023 年可能会达到这一水平。这是疫情爆发前通常收到的金额的两倍。 ;外国直接投资;目前占波兰资本支出的 25%，而工业化国家的平均比例为 5% 左右。

;

;部分资金来自德国工程公司博世和日本企业集团大金，这两家公司都在该国建设热泵工厂。根据咨询公司 ;E;&;Y; 的一项调查，67% 的“国际决策者”预计其公司在欧洲的业务将会增长，高于 2021 年的 40% . 这可能包括将为非洲大陆不断壮大的武装部队提供产品的国防公司以及中国的;电动汽车;制造商。

;

;但大部分重组都不会那么令人愉快。德国最大的汽车零部件供应商之一大陆集团正在裁员数千人。博世正在裁减其汽车软件部门的 1,200 个职位。汽车行业的其他公司也宣布了裁员。之前的中国冲击刺激了技术进步，因为工人们纷纷转向生产力更高、投资于创新的公司。但根据奥地利经济研究所克劳斯·弗里森比希勒 (Klaus Friesenbichler) 及其合著者的研究，在过去 15 年左右的时间里，面临中国竞争的企业已显示出生产率增长放缓的迹象。

;

;虽然德国是欧洲的制造业强国，但三重挑战可能会影响整个欧洲大陆。西欧拥有能源密集型产业或生产大众市场产品的地区可能会遭受损失。即使是未受到最初影响的地区，成功的本土企业也可能会加大海外投资，因为它们适应了其他地方的保护主义。欧洲央行的一项调查显示，未来五年，欧元区约 75% 的大型企业预计将实现跨国家多元化，将生产更接近销售，或将部分业务转移到政治上更加一致的国家。小>;。

;

;老问题

;

;资金紧张的情况是有限的政府可以采取措施缓解向新产业的过渡。当他们承诺增加国防开支并且几乎不希望进行能够刺激经济增长的大规模<小>;欧盟;改革时，情况尤其如此。该集团; ;最近批准了七个国家在几年内为云计算提供 12 亿欧元的公共补贴。正如另一家智库麦肯锡全球研究所指出的那样，这相当于亚马逊网络服务年度投资的 4% 左右。前沿技术的专利主要由美国和中国公司注册。尽管人口众多，欧盟在许多方面都缺乏规模。内部货物贸易远非无缝。服务市场一如既往地分散。

;

;这就留下了第二种方法——寻求保留旧的——对此游说非常激烈。在民粹主义右翼复兴的时代，很少有政客愿意因失业而受到指责。深化资本市场或整合电力市场等困难的技术性工作的回报不会很快到来。在布鲁塞尔和巴黎，无益的补贴和其他形式的保护主义的呼声日益高涨。与此同时，德国受到三党联盟的阻碍，该联盟无法在任何问题上达成一致，更不用说在跨越地缘政治和产业政策的棘手问题上达成一致了。随着政客们的搪塞，更多的比亚迪船只将驶往欧洲港口。 ;■;

;;L;;多一点; 一个多月前，塞内加尔正处于宪法危机之中。 ;麦基·萨尔;，即将卸任的总统曾试图将选举推迟十个月。他最受欢迎的竞争对手入狱并被取消竞选资格。安全部队殴打并逮捕抗议者。许多人担心，一个被广泛视为该地区稳定堡垒的国家将再次陷入;政变;和逾期总统可能是下一张倒下的多米诺骨牌。

;

;但是事实证明，末日论者是错误的。 3 月 24 日，大批选民前来投票，对萨尔先生坎坷的 12 年执政生涯做出评价。在几乎完全顺利通过的民意调查中，他们为反腐败斗士巴西鲁·迪奥马耶·法耶 (Bassirou Diomaye Faye) 赢得了轻松多数，作为最后一刻特赦协议的一部分，他在投票前不到两周就被释放出狱。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;在第一个结果公布后的几个小时内，执政党候选人阿马杜·巴(Amadou Ba)大方地接受了失败。萨勒先生为削弱塞内加尔的机构做了很多工作，去年曾考虑竞选宪法规定禁止的第三个任期，他对投票的和平结束表示欢迎，“这是塞内加尔民主的胜利。”

;

;44 岁的费耶先生将成为非洲最年轻的民选领导人。他加入了一个新兴的千禧一代男性俱乐部，他们最近在几个西非国家——几内亚、马里，以及更远的尼日尔和布基纳法索——至少部分是由于民众对老龄化领导人和掠夺性精英的不满。费耶先生在这一群体中是独一无二的，因为他是通过投票而非政变上台的。然而，塞内加尔的当选总统代表了对地区不安全、长期失业和前殖民国家法国干预的同样广泛的民粹主义反应。

;

;从未担任过民选公职的费耶先生宣称，他的胜利是对“破裂”对连续性的投票。他承诺遏制腐败并削减总统权力。在选举之前，他采取了不同寻常的举措，以透明的名义公布了自己的净资产。更具争议性的是，他建议放弃法国支持的区域货币非洲金融共同体法郎，并重新谈判其前任授予外国投资者的石油和天然气许可证。

;

;费耶先生的背后隐藏着奥斯曼·桑科 (Ousmane Sonko) 的身影，他是他最亲密的盟友，也是迄今为止塞内加尔最受欢迎的反对派领导人。桑科先生是一位富有魅力的煽动者，令该国的政界和商界感到不安。去年，萨尔先生在接受《经济学人》采访时指责他煽动暴力。 （事实上​​，反对派领袖曾经告诉他的追随者：“如果你强行打开[当权者]的房屋，你会发现里面有数十亿美元。”）

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;先生Sonko 于 2021 年被捕并被指控强奸。尽管这项指控被无罪释放，但他仍被判犯有“青少年腐败”罪，即对 21 岁以下人士的不道德行为。他还因指控政府部长腐败而被判诽谤罪。他表示这些指控是出于政治动机，并否认有不当行为。但他的定罪使他没有资格竞选总统，即使他与费耶先生一起出狱后，费耶先生立即取代他成为该党的总统候选人。

;

;两人都是前税务稽查员，彼此共事多年。据说他们是紧密相连的：据报道，费耶先生为了纪念他的朋友，给他的儿子起了个绰号“奥斯曼”。出狱后，他们以“迪奥马耶就是松科”的口号开展竞选活动。费耶是两人中比较保守的一个，他尚未透露他的朋友是否会担任政府正式职务。但即使他不这样做，分裂的桑科先生无疑也会在幕后发挥重大影响力。达卡（Dakar）智囊团Afrikajom Center的Alioune Tine说：“他们将在同时合作。” “这是他们的联合项目。”

;

;该项目的确切详细信息仍然模糊。当选总统费耶先生在他的第一次演讲中承诺要以“谦卑”来统治。在投票前的日子里，他试图安抚外国投资者，宣布自己是所有竞争者在总统职位的竞争者中最有力的保证人，同时向他的承诺浇水，以替换; cfa ;。国家货币。 （尽管在该地区被广泛看作是殖民时代的遗物，但这种共同货币有助于遏制通货膨胀和货币波动。）也许试图让他和Sonko先生与法国削减联系，并为俄罗斯打开俄罗斯之门，即将上任的总统在就职演讲中还强调，塞内加尔将对所有“尊重”的外国伴侣仍然是“安全可靠的盟友”。

;

;与抛弃; cfa ;法郎相比，对烃合同的审查可能是更高的优先级。但是在这里，Faye先生的机动空间也有限。塞内加尔;塞内加尔的公共债务中有81％的人在经过十年的主要基础设施支出后不舒服。最近发现的石油和天然气储量带来的令人期待的意外之财尚未落地，进一步加剧了财政紧缩。由于开始生产的延迟，去年年底，IMF ;今年对塞内加尔的增长预测下降了2个以上，至（仍然是Zippy）8.3％。塞内加尔智库 Think Africa 2050 的联合创始人梅耶科·萨尔 (Mayecor Sar) 表示，“以诗歌进行竞选，以散文进行治理”。 “我认为这里也是如此。”

;

;现在，塞内加尔的情绪是合理的。事实证明，人们担心其民主制度可能会屈服于街头暴力，甚至政变。就像2017年肯尼亚和2020年马拉维的法官一样，塞内加尔最高法院的法官也坚定地反对企图颠覆宪法并挖掘选举。比赛结果一出，所有其他参赛者都立即认输，纷纷涌来祝贺获胜者。 “对于民主来说，这确实是一个很好的结果，”萨尔先生说。 “正是塞内加尔人民的民主意识使这一切变得不同。” ;■;

;杀手鲸（; orcinus orca ;）是一个多样的物种，在世界各地拥有几个孤立的人群，占据了各种孤立的人群，而占据不同的情况，而且在某些情况下，几乎没有描述的情况，还没有描述过生态学。利基。最近的两项研究已经揭示了杀手鲸的独特狩猎文化，这些鲸鱼的独特狩猎文化缠在东北太平洋的深水中。

;

;研究最多的虎鲸生态型是占据东北太平洋海岸线（从阿拉斯加北部到加利福尼亚南部）的三种虎鲸生态型。 “近海”虎鲸长达 6.6 米，以 100 至 200 头的群体在遥远的水域巡逻，捕食鲨鱼等中上层鱼类。 “常驻”虎鲸长约 7 米，成群结队地在海岸线游荡，数量多达 25 头，以沿海鱼类（主要是鲑鱼）为食。最后，“短暂的”虎鲸每头长达 8 米，分布在沿海浅水区和深水区，捕食海洋哺乳动物，包括鲸目动物（鲸鱼和海豚）以及鳍足类动物（海狮和海豹）。 While “inner coast” transients stalk shallow waters near the shore, “outer coast” transients hunt in the deep open waters along canyons at the edge of the continental shelf.

;

;To understand these transient killer whales better, Josh McInnes from the University of British Columbia in Canada led a team that analysed 261 sightings of killer whales around the Monterey Submarine Canyon System collected by surveys and whale-watching vessels. The dataset included almost 100 predation events. Publishing their results in the journal ;;PLOS ONE;;, Mr McInnes found patterns in behaviour of outer coast transients that differed from those of their inner coast cousins. The latter ambushed harbour seals, sea lions and the occasional otter, while the former tended to perform co-ordinated dives in their hunt for larger mammalian prey.

;;

;(Cetacean needed)

;

;Outer coast transients appear to have developed specialised strategies—such as the repeated battering and drowning of grey whale calves—because their prey is bigger and takes more time to subdue. Like most specialised killer-whale hunting behaviours, these strategies are thought to be honed, down the generations, as a form of cultural knowledge.

;

;在研究外海岸瞬态现象时，麦金尼斯先生还偶然发现了一些此前未曾描述过的虎鲸种群的迹象，这些虎鲸是完全不同类别的大型猎物捕猎者。 Writing in the journal ;Aquatic Mammals;, his team described nine offshore encounters with 49 killer whales between 1997 and 2021. These killer whales were seen killing sperm whales, pygmy sperm whales and large ;Risso's dolphins;, as well as scavenging on leatherback turtles.

;
;
;
;
;;
;

;The attack on sperm whales, which can grow to around 10 times larger than adult killer whales, was a particularly impressive show of predatory力量。 1997 年 10 月 21 日，人们观察到 15 到 35 头虎鲸在四个小时内猎杀了一群 9 头抹香鲸。抹香鲸遭到一波又一波的攻击，所有抹香鲸都受伤，其中几头受重伤，最后一只抹香鲸从鲸群中被隔离并被杀死。 Out of the surviving sperm whales, three are thought to have died from the wounds they sustained and it is possible the entire herd later succumbed to its injuries.

;

;Little more than that is known about these killer whales for now, except that they are identifiable by characteristic circular scars left by bites from cookie-cutter sharks, which suggest these hyper-aggressive creatures stalk the deep waters of the north Pacific.

;

;More data, especially of the genetic kind, will need to be collected from both outer coast transient killer whales as well as their newly discovered cousins terrorising the pelagic waters of the north Pacific, before scientists can fully describe the new ecotypes and add them to marine biology textbooks. Nevertheless, the discoveries are a reminder that biodiversity is not just about the diversity between species but also within them. Killer whales seem to exist in many more shades than just black and white. ;■;

;; W;;hen Julia Donaldson ;set out to write a children's book featuring a mouse—who would take a stroll through “the deep dark wood”, fending off a series of predators with wit and cunning— she intended him to meet a ;tiger for tea;。 Ms Donaldson, a British author who wrote songs for children's television, had been inspired by a Chinese fable about a girl who escapes death by convincing a tiger that she is the queen of the forest.但有一个问题：唐纳森女士希望这本书是押韵的对联，而不是与老虎太多押韵。 She decided it would be more pragmatic for the beast's name to end with the sound “oh”. And so, with the help of Axel Scheffler, a German illustrator, one of the most lucrative monsters in children's publishing was born.

;

;“The Gruffalo”, which was published 25 years ago in March, has achieved such great success that tired parents everywhere have considered jacking in their boring jobs to write children's books.; ;To date it has sold 11.6m copies worldwide, according to the publisher. Last year Ms Donaldson's whole oeuvre—now 200 books and counting—brought in £15.6m ($19.6m) in sales, with “The Gruffalo” leading the pack.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;当孩子在睡前选择一些书时，有些书会让大人在心里呻吟，而《咕噜牛》读起来几乎和听起来一样有趣。与大多数以动物为主题的寓言一样，它有一个不特定的背景和普遍的主题——弱者的胜利、大脑战胜肌肉——这有助于它引起年轻和年老观众的共鸣。 Credit is also owed to Mr Scheffler, an illustrator with the most recognisable style since Quentin Blake (who collaborated with ;Roald Dahl;). Mr Scheffler has said initial sketches “were deemed to be 'too scary for tiny children' by the editor so I had to make him a bit rounder and more 'cuddly'.” The result resembles one of the terrible creatures from Maurice Sendek's “Where the Wild Things Are” (1963), another classic.

;

;Today you can buy Gruffalo-branded slippers, cushions and crisps (cheese-and-onion Gruffalo claws, anyone?); get tickets to the stage show; and keep a toddler quiet for half an hour with the Oscar-winning short film featuring the voices of James Corden and Robbie Coltrane. Many fans think that the book's sequel, “The Gruffalo's Child”, is—like “The Godfather Part II” and ;“Top Gun: Maverick”;—even better than the original.

;

;At the last count “The Gruffalo” has appeared in 107 languages and dialects, including Armenian, Basque, Esperanto,; ;Kurdish and Thai, making it the second-most translated children's book of recent times. Only “The Little Prince” by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, first published in 1943, has racked up more foreign editions, says Michele Young, rights director at Macmillan Children's Books, the publisher of “The Gruffalo” in Britain.

;

;Because its fame now seems like a foregone conclusion, it is easy to forget that the book defied early expectations. Before Ms Donaldson “paved the way” for other authors, editors were nervous about books that rhymed, according to Ms Young. It was hard to sell the rights to international publishers, because poetry is notoriously difficult to translate.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Vladimir Nabokov thought translating rhyme was so challenging that writers should not bother. In the introduction to his translation of “Eugene Onegin”, which rendered ;Alexander Pushkin;'s Russian verse into English prose, the novelist spelt out his belief that translators should be as faithful to the original text as possible.他写道：“要再现韵律，同时按字面意思翻译整首诗，从数学上来说是不可能的。” Happily for children and parents who do not speak English, most translators of “The Gruffalo” ignored Nabokov's pleas. Instead they have chosen to channel poets such as Alexander Pope, whose translation of Homer's “Iliad” captures the spirit of the original rather than striving for verisimilitude.

;;

;Of mice and men

;

;Andy Smart, who translated “The Gruffalo” into Arabic with his wife, Nadia Fouda, distilled the pair's modus operandi to: “Keep the mood, keep the rhyme, don't lose the humour.” Their version, in which the pictures have been flipped so it can be read from right to left, is one of the few to change the name of the Gruffalo: to “;Gharfoul;”, a made-up word drawing on “ghoul”, because it was easier to rhyme in Arabic.

;

;The need to make lines rhyme and scan, coupled with a translator's desire to give their own spin to the text, leads to delightful variations. Whereas Ms Donaldson's last line in the original English is “The mouse found a nut and the nut was good”, the Italian mouse gets a closing soliloquy: “Mmmh, è squisita! Che bella giornata! Che dolce è la vita!” (“Mmm, it's delicious. What a beautiful day! How sweet life is!”).

;

;Gruffalo connoisseurs can have fun spotting the differences between what the mouse claims are the Gruffalo's favourite foods, in a successful ploy to scare off predators. In the German version, “roasted fox” becomes “Fuchsspieß” (fox kebab). The Japanese translator has turned “scrambled snake” into “snake ;kabayaki;”, adapting a traditional dish of grilled fish, while in the French version it becomes “crème de serpent”; ;(“cream of snake”). Such local adaptation makes “The Gruffalo” a perfect treat; ;before bed, wherever you are. ;■;

We saw in their experience the signs of how ;AI; could disrupt this global year of elections.

;

;One such sign is the rise of ;AI;-powered video, in particular deepfakes—content created to convince people of events that did not occur. One video aired on TikTok, a Chinese-owned platform, showed Taiwanese presidential candidate William Lai endorsing his rivals' joint opposition ticket.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Deepfakes are just one of several tactics being developed for video-based propaganda. CapCut, an app produced by Bytedance, TikTok's parent company, uses ;AI; to generate videos from text descriptions. CapCut was reportedly used by Spamouflage, a China-linked foreign-influence campaign, to turn written propaganda into ;AI;-generated newscasts.这些视频并不完全是深度伪造的：很少有观众会认为此类广播是真实的。 But they mark disinformation's expansion to video-based platforms. As online attention shifts from tweets to TikTok, disinformation is following.

;

;AI also makes it easier to pump out media about events as soon as they发生。选举前几天，所有台湾注册的电话同时响起由一颗中国卫星飞越台湾领空引发的空袭警报。 Within 24 hours Taiwan ;AI; Labs, a research outfit, observed over 1,500 co-ordinated social-media posts promoting conspiracy theories about the alert and sowing distrust.一度每分钟出现多达五个。 Many were far more readable than the stuff produced by a typical content mill.

;

;In the three months leading up to the elections, Cloudflare, an internet-services provider, found that efforts to crash Taiwanese websites jumped by 3,370% compared to the same period the year before. Had these sites been taken down in large numbers, Taiwanese residents seeking information online would instead have seen a deluge of disinformation on social media. This is what happened after Hawaii's wildfires in 2023, when Spamouflage spread ;AI;-generated conspiracy theories.

;

;Many Taiwanese feel as if their country is desperately adding sandbags to its levees the night before a typhoon.政府机构和研究组织缺乏及时跟踪视频内容的工具。 Fact-checkers struggle to keep pace: during Taiwan's 2020 presidential election Cofacts, a fact-checking platform, was able to respond to around 80% of incoming requests within 24 hours. This year, on election day, it managed to respond to just 15% of requests.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Worse, technology companies lack effective technical countermeasures against disinformation distributed by states. They are increasingly using “watermarks”, digital branding of content as ;AI;-generated, and content policies to prevent their proprietary ;AI; from being abused by others. But well-resourced states can build their own ;AI; that is unimpeded by watermarking and content-policy constraints. Tech firms are also focused on building tools for detecting ;AI;-generated content, but Taiwanese disinformation-fighters say these provide conflicting and inaccurate results.

;

;;AI;-generated disinformation requires a broad response that involves governments, technology companies, fact-checking outfits and think-tanks.大型科技公司应该帮助资助事实核查人员和其他提供一线情报的私营部门组织。 They should also share more of their data with civil-society groups, whose local knowledge and legitimacy mean they are well placed to track accounts and counter false narratives in their countries of operation.

;

;Front-line organisations need to be on the video-sharing platforms, of course, both to monitor them and to create and share content.不过，有些人有理由对 TikTok 保持警惕。 In Taiwan, just one of the major fact-checking and disinformation-research organisations has a TikTok account, owing to concerns about the app's Chinese ownership.

;

;This means ceding a front—and a potentially powerful tool. A study by ;USC; Annenberg, a journalism school, in 2017 showed that video-based fact-checking is more effective than text-checking at correcting the beliefs of users exposed to disinformation. In 2022 a study in ;Science Advances;, a journal, found that “prebunking” videos, which are designed to pre-empt disinformation—before an election, say, or after a natural disaster—worked even across political divides, offering viewers on both left and right a certain level of inoculation.

;

;Taiwanese civil-society organisations avoid TikTok because they doubt they would be treated fairly on a Chinese-owned platform. Taiwan's government has concluded that there is no legal basis for a blanket ban on TikTok and that it lacks the power to require Chinese disinvestment from the platform—a move being considered by lawmakers in America, where, unlike in Taiwan, TikTok has a subsidiary. That means Taiwan, and others in a similar situation, will have to find ways to better monitor TikTok.

;

;That will require sharper tools. The best available open-source tools for monitoring video content, such as the ;EU;-funded InVid, focus on verification (enabling reverse image searches, magnifying details and so on). This painstaking approach made sense before generative ;AI;, when the question was about whether the claims or images in a particular video could be trusted.但问题的规模和变化的速度已经发展到这种方法不再有效的地步。相反，挑战在于弄清楚新的叙述何时传播（以及向谁传播）并迅速反击。 Disinformation-fighters don't yet have the tools for video-monitoring at scale or the methods to track what content algorithms are suppressing or amplifying.

;

;Disinformation has reached an inflection point in a year when more than half the world's population lives in countries that will hold nationwide elections. Malicious actors will be using ;AI; to make falsehoods more engaging and believable and to distort narratives in moments of crisis. Those who wish to safeguard 2024's elections must be ready to tell their story before others tell it for them.;■;

;;A;;N ANONYMOUS MEMO; briefly circled the web in March.作者自称是麦肯锡前合伙人，他们斥责这家著名的战略咨询公司近年来追求“不受控制和不受管理的增长”，并斥责其领导层“缺乏战略重点”。 With humility typical of McKinseyites, they warned that “an organisation of genuine greatness” was at risk of being lost.

;

;The memo, which was swiftly taken down, is but the latest murmur of discontent at McKinsey.今年一月，其管理合伙人鲍勃·斯特恩费尔斯(Bob Sternfels)在第一轮投票中未能获得大多数高级合伙人对连任的支持，被迫参加最高职位的内部竞争。 Although he ultimately prevailed, the saga hinted at the trouble brewing within the firm.

;;
;;
;

;Not long ago the consulting industry looked indestructible. Fees rocketed during the covid-19 pandemic as clients sped up efforts to digitise their businesses, diversify their supply chains and respond to growing calls to bolster their environmental, social and governance (;ESG;) credentials. The consulting revenues of the industry's most important firms—including the triumvirate of strategy advisers (Bain, ;BCG; and McKinsey), the “big four” accounting giants (Deloitte, ;EY;, ;KPMG; and ;P;w;C;) and Accenture (also the world's largest outsourcer)—grew by 20% in 2021 and then 13% in 2022 (see chart).

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Since then, however, growth has been soggy for this “great eight”, slowing to around 5% in 2023, according to estimates from Kennedy Research Reports, an industry-watcher, and calculations by ;The Economist;, based on company filings. Clients grappling with inflation and economic uncertainty have cut back on splashy projects. A dearth of mergers and acquisitions has led to a slump in demand for support with due diligence and company integrations.

;

;That has caused a headache for the consultancies. When demand from clients looked limitless, they recruited staff like there was no tomorrow. Revenues at McKinsey are up by a third since 2019—but headcount is up by half, to 45,000. As job opportunities at startups and private-equity firms have withered, fewer consultants have left the firms of their own accord, reversing the spike in attrition rates during the pandemic.

;

;Now tomorrow is here, with a vengeance. Bain and Deloitte have paid some; ;graduates to delay their start dates. Newbie consultants at some firms complain that there is too little work to go around, stunting their career prospects. Lay-offs have become widespread. All of the big four have made cuts to their advisory teams. Last year Accenture, the only one of the eight that is publicly listed, said it would fire 19,000 staff. On March 21st it reported that its consulting revenues for the quarter to February shrunk by 3%, year on year, after flattening in the previous quarter.

;

;The consulting industry has made it through choppy waters before, including during the dotcom crash and the global financial crisis. Yet its recovery this time will be complicated by three issues. The first is geopolitics. The consulting giants, all of which are based in the West, have benefited from decades of globalisation during which they spread their tendrils into every corner of the globe. Deloitte, the biggest of the bunch by consulting revenues, has offices in more than 150 countries and territories.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;That is now placing the firms in awkward spots. Last month it surfaced that the Urban China Initiative, a think-tank co-founded by McKinsey, provided advice to the Chinese government in 2015 that helped shape its “Made in China 2025” plan, which has sought to reduce the economy's reliance on foreign know-how and place China at the forefront of sectors from electric vehicles to artificial intelligence. Although McKinsey denied that it wrote the report, some American lawmakers have called for the firm to be barred from American government contracts. In the 12 months to September 2023 the federal government paid McKinsey more than $100m in fees.

;

;Now China is also starting to squeeze foreign advisers out of its market. Last year Dentons, a global law firm, unwound its tie-up with Dacheng, a Chinese one, in response to new cybersecurity and data-protection rules that made the combination unworkable. Although China is yet to produce a homegrown consulting powerhouse, it has already begun to make life difficult for foreign ones. Staff in Bain's Shanghai office were questioned by Chinese authorities a year ago, for reasons unknown. On March 22nd it was reported that the Chinese government was scrutinising ;P;w;C;'s auditing work at Evergrande, a bankrupt Chinese property developer that has been accused of fraudulently inflating its revenues 。 That could weigh on ;P;w;C;'s consulting business in the country.

;

;It is not only the West's relationship with China that is causing problems. In February the bosses of ;BCG;,; ;McKinsey; ;and Teneo, a smaller consultancy, along with Michael Klein, a dealmaker, were hauled before a congressional committee in Washington after failing to hand over details of their work for Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund. The committee is investigating Saudi Arabia's efforts to build “soft power” in America through, for example, its investments in sports such as golf. McKinsey and ;BCG; said that their staff in Saudi Arabia could be imprisoned if they divulged details of their work for the country's sovereign wealth fund. The Persian Gulf has been a rare bright spot for the consultants of late, with the oil-rich states splashing out on advice as they seek to diversify their economies.

;

;Waning enthusiasm for ;ESG;, denounced by critics as “woke capitalism”, presents a second threat to the industry's recovery. In recent years the consulting giants have spent big on building out their ;ESG ;offerings, especially around decarbonisation. In 2021 McKinsey acquired three sustainability consultancies. In 2022 Accenture gobbled up five. So far these investments seem to be paying off. Christoph Schweizer, the boss of ;BCG;, which acquired the environmental consultancy Quantis in 2022, says that sustainability was one of his firm's fastest-growing areas of work last year.

;

;Whether that growth will continue at the same pace is less clear. In America Republican-run states including Florida and Texas have withdrawn funds parked with BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, in protest over its use of ;ESG; considerations when making investments. Consulting clients surveyed in January by Source Global Research, another industry analyst, ranked sustainability projects tenth in their list of priorities for the year, down from fourth in 2023. Some consulting grandees admit that certain clients are reining in their climate ambitions. According to one, that is in part because their customers are proving more resistant to paying the resulting premium.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The third and thorniest challenge that lies ahead for the great eight is technological change. For many years clients sought their help to modernise creaky old systems. Increasingly, the consultants themselves are grappling with digital disruption. The boss of a big buy-out firm says that his dealmakers are turning to software tools and data providers rather than pricey consultants for some of the analysis needed to evaluate a target company. Other tasks that legions of consultants once spent hours on, like compiling and categorising data on a company's spending habits, can now be done at the push of a button.

;

;The consultants are not standing idle. Bain, for example, has redesigned the way it does due diligence on companies, incorporating nifty tools such as web-scraping programs. The firms are also racing to stay one step ahead of artificial intelligence (;AI;). Last August McKinsey launched Lilli, a Chat;GPT;-like bot trained on its corpus of frameworks and other intellectual property, which consultants can use to speed up their work. Others have followed suit.

;

;Excitement among clients over such “generative” ;AI ;is also creating opportunities for the consultants 。 Mr Schweizer says that ;BCG ;has already completed hundreds of projects with clients around the technology. Accenture has booked $1.1bn worth of generative-;AI; work in the past six months. Much of this is happening in collaboration with the tech companies developing the ;AI;s. Accenture has been working with Microsoft. In March the consulting firm also announced a partnership with Cohere, an ;AI;-model builder with which McKinsey has buddied up, too. Bain has an alliance with Open;AI;, the maker of Chat;GPT;. ;BCG; has a collaboration with Anthropic, one more ;AI; firm.

;

;Such partnerships look like a welcome source of growth for the consultants. In time, though, they could become a drag—especially if they are successful. The quicker corporate clients become comfortable with chatbots, the faster they may simply go directly to their makers in Silicon Valley. If that happens, the great eight's short-term gains from ;AI ;could lead them towards irrelevance. That is something for all the strategy brains to stew on. ;■;

;To assess Rwanda today one can look at Mr Kagame's policies in three distinct places: at home, in the wider Great Lakes region , and in the rest of the world. Across them a picture emerges of some reform and reconciliation, with a lot of repression and realpolitik. Central to Mr Kagame's domestic agenda is state-enforced brainwashing. At ;ingando; (“solidarity”) camps and in prisons, an official narrative is drummed into the population. It is a story that emphasises a national Rwandan identity over ethnic ones and that does not mention any of the crimes committed by Mr Kagame's party, the Rwandan Patriotic Front (;RPF;).

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;For the government, the case for top-down reconciliation is obvious given that perpetrators live cheek by jowl with the families of victims. Has it worked? A state-sponsored “reconciliation barometer” shows that nearly 100% of Rwandans respond positively to questions about whether they are tolerant, trusting and united. Phil Clark of the School of Oriental and African Studies at the University of London, has written that “most Rwandans… have chosen to get on with life rather than settle old scores”.

;

;Other researchers argue that in Rwanda reconciliation is often superficial. Susan Thomson of Colgate University has described “everyday resistance” to government schemes. This includes people keeping silent or even laughing during community meetings, and passing critical messages clandestinely at vegetable markets.

;

;Though it is impossible to see into the hearts of ordinary Rwandans, one can see the repression that has come with reconciliation. Expansive laws banning “divisionism” and genocide denial are used against dissidents. A system in which neighbours spy on one another keeps close tabs on villagers. Journalists and opposition politicians have been imprisoned and some have died in mysterious circumstances. Opponents of the regime outside the country have been harassed and, in some cases, killed.

;

;Rwanda prefers it when visitors focus on Kigali's clean streets, its gleaming convention centre, the lack of petty corruption and its mountain gorillas. Western diplomats praise Rwanda's effective use of aid, which adds up to the equivalent of around 75% of government spending. Such is the interest from other African officials that there is now a dedicated agency explaining how they can use Rwanda's methods. It is a sign of what Ken Opalo, a Kenyan academic, calls “Rwanda envy”.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Some of that is justified. ;GDP; grew by more than 8% a year on average from 1995 to 2022. Life expectancy increased from 49 years to 66 between 2001 and 2021. Child mortality fell by 77%.

;

;Yet there may be less to Rwanda's success than meets the eye. Several researchers have credibly suggested that official measures of poverty underestimate its true extent. Others have questioned official data on agricultural yields. Just 2% of Rwandans have fridges, a symbol of African middle-class life. That is well below the rate in other countries such as Ethiopia (6%) and Tanzania (10%) that have similar income levels, according to the Global Data Lab based at Radboud University in the Netherlands.

;

;In private many Rwandans complain about big gaps between the rich and poor. The country has a higher Gini coefficient, a benchmark for income inequality, than regional peers. A sense that the gains from growth are heavily skewed to a narrow elite could be socially dangerous. One study suggests that Tutsis, who make up 10-15% of the population, hold 80% of top jobs in government and state-owned firms such as Crystal Ventures, which is run by the ;RPF;, and Horizon, which is run by the army. Some scholars praise these firms for investing in the economy, though they can also deter investors by stifling competition.

;

;Yet Mr Kagame's ambitions have never been limited by his country's borders. In the 1980s he and other Tutsi exiles in Uganda helped Yoweri Museveni take power in that country. In the early 1990s the ;RPF; went to war against the then Hutu-led regime in Rwanda, and in 1994 they marched on Kigali to end the genocide, which was sparked when a plane carrying Juvenal Habyarimana, Rwanda's president, was shot down. In 1997 Mr Kagame and Mr Museveni together toppled Mobutu Sese Soku, Congo's dictator for three decades, after he gave sanctuary to Rwandan army and militia leaders who had participated in the genocide. When the man they replaced him with, Laurent Kabila, proved less than pliant, Rwanda invaded again, instigating a war that led to the loss of 1m-5m lives, mostly from hunger and disease.

;

;Rwanda, which seems to export more minerals than it mines at home, has retained a strong presence in resource-rich regions of eastern Congo. According to the ;UN,; it supports an armed group known as ;M;23, which is accused of murder and rape and is close to capturing the regional capital, Goma, increasing tension between Congo and Rwanda. “War could break out at any time,” worries a Western diplomat.

;

;Rwanda's sympathisers argue that its actions in eastern Congo are about self-defence and the protection of Tutsis. The Rwandan government points out that there are links between the Congolese army and a group known as ;FDLR;, which traces its origins to the Hutu genocidaires who fled in 1994. Yet there is more to Rwanda's meddling. The latest spasm of violence by ;M;23 followed Congo's moves to sideline Rwanda by inviting Burundian and Uganda troops into the country, and by drawing closer to Kenya's economic orbit. Michela Wrong, a journalist, wrote last year that: “Kagame has long believed in his right to be ;incontournable; [“unavoidable”] not only in Rwanda but also in the region, on the continent, and even in the global arena.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Some of the early aid to Rwanda was motivated by Western guilt at having failed to intervene to stop the genocide; some because Rwanda was proof that aid to Africa could actually work. Increasingly, though, it is Mr Kagame's transactional realpolitik that ensures the support of Western countries. Britain, for instance, wants to send asylum seekers there. Some in Rwanda's government regret the deal because they see it as tarnishing its brand, but there have been benefits. Britain has agreed to pay £370m ($470m) for the “partnership” by 2026, about ten times more than its annual aid contributions to the country, with more cash if asylum-seekers ever arrive. That contrasts with Britain's response in 2012 to an ;M;23 offensive, when it cut aid to Rwanda.

;

;France, too, is cosying up to Mr Kagame. For years relations were strained because a French judge accused the ;RPF ;of shooting down the plane carrying Habyarimana, whose regime Paris supported. Emmanuel Macron, who in 2021 in Kigali asked for forgiveness for France's role during the genocide, has repaired relations. The ;EU; is funding Rwanda's deployment against jihadists in Mozambique, near where Total, a French energy giant, is building a huge gas project. In February, to the ire of Congo, the bloc announced an agreement to boost mineral exports from Rwanda.

;

;America has taken a tougher stance. It has imposed sanctions on a Rwandan general for his alleged role in supporting ;M;23 and has suspended military aid. But America remains Rwanda's largest donor and it is reluctant to alienate Mr Kagame, an ally with a strong army that he is willing to send to unstable parts of Africa. Rwanda's leader also knows his way around Washington; in February he wooed Congressmen at a prayer breakfast. (By contrast, a South African delegation turned up during recess and struggled to meet anyone.)

;

;Indeed, Rwanda has seemingly managed to stay friends with those across several political divides. China has built most of Rwanda's major roads and sells it weaponry. Mr Kagame has praised Russia's role in Africa—yet will be one of a few African countries to soon host a new Ukrainian embassy. Rwanda expressed sympathy with Israel after the massacre by Hamas on October 7th, but has also sent baby formula to Gaza. Qatar is a major investor in Rwanda but this month Kigali welcomed a delegation from the its rival, the United Arab Emirates. “Kagame understands that, ultimately, diplomacy is all about interests,” says a diplomat.

;

;When Rwanda's leader speaks on April 7th there will be many foreign dignitaries in attendance. When he wins re-election in July, few of them will speak out. There is a grim logic to such reticence: Mr Kagame will be calling the shots for at least another decade. But as his fourth decade in charge of Rwanda begins, the outside world may want to ponder a question. How stable can Rwanda really be, if it depends on the rule of just one man? ;■;

;;E;;ARLIER THIS; year, a common view was that the war in Ukraine was ;settling into a stalemate;, after the failure of the Ukrainian counter-offensive last summer. That now seems optimistic. There is an alarming possibility that a big new Russian push in the next few months could punch through Ukraine's defences and deep into the country.

;

;Since the ;fall of Avdiivka; in February, a bitterly fought-over coking town in Donetsk province, Russian forces have been pressing hard across several axes in eastern Ukraine. Although Russia paid a high price in blood and equipment to take Avdiivka—up to 17,000 soldiers may have been killed and many hundreds of tanks and other armoured fighting vehicles destroyed—its forces are pushing as far west of the town as they can in an effort to prevent Ukraine from forming stronger defensive lines there. So far, they have only taken some seven to ten kilometres at best. But a bigger push is expected in the summer.

;;
;;
;

;“The next five to six months could be critical,” says Konrad Muzyka, an analyst at Rochan Consulting and author of the “Ukraine Conflict Monitor”, a website. The priorities for Ukraine, according to Michael Kofman of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, are “manpower, fortifications and ammunition”.

;

;Ukraine has performed miracles in pushing back Russia's Black Sea Fleet and reopening grain exports from Odessa. And it is conducting an air campaign against infrastructure targets in Russia, especially oil refineries, using home-made drones. It is hitting Russia so hard that America has become concerned about the global oil price. But this remains primarily a ground war.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Ukraine is suffering from acute “shell hunger”, which is why it was forced to withdraw from Avdiivka. By prolific use of drones, the Ukrainians have been able to compensate partially for rationed shells. But drones cannot concentrate fire in the way that artillery can. The blocking of the Biden administration's $61bn military-support package by pro-Donald Trump Republicans in Congress since last year has had direct consequences on the battlefield. So too has the failure of a European Union plan to come up with more than half of the million shells it had promised to deliver by this month.

;

;Across the front, Russia is firing at least five shells for every Ukrainian one. Although the Biden administration's support bill remains hostage to electoral politics, Europe is only belatedly rising to the challenge. With Russia now churning out some 3m artillery shells a year and receiving additional stocks from North Korea and Iran, Europe expects to be able to produce just 1.4m shells a year by the end of 2024, rising to 2m late next  year.

;

;The best prospect for alleviating Ukraine's plight is an initiative that the Czech government has been quietly working on since the war began. The Czechs have scoured the world for supplies of munitions and have now sourced about 800,000 shells. Several countries, including Germany, the Netherlands, Denmark and Canada have stumped up money to help pay for it. If €3bn ($3.3bn) could be scraped together, say the Czechs, they could get their hands on 1.5m shells. Nico Lange, a Ukraine expert who is a former official at the German defence ministry, says that some of the shells have started to arrive, albeit in small amounts. They will, he adds, give the troops at the front “breathing space” over the next couple of months.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Other types of munitions are also in short supply. Ukraine is running perilously low on air-defence interceptors. On the night of March 21st-22nd, which saw the biggest attack on Ukraine's energy system since the war began, out of 151 missiles and drones launched by Russia, only 92 were intercepted. Since then there have been further attacks on critical infrastructure in the western city of Lviv and on Kyiv.

;

;Ukraine also urgently needs more ways to hit targets in Crimea and logistics hubs deep behind enemy lines. It has probably used up a large proportion of the Storm Shadow and Scalp cruise missiles that Britain and France donated. They showed their value again on March 24th when two more large Russian landing ships were hit off the occupied port of Sevastopol. Germany's chancellor Olaf Sholz has dug in his heels over the supply of the even more powerful Taurus missiles. Ukraine is also running low on tanks and other fighting vehicles, though there is some hope that America could send it hundreds of mothballed Bradley Fighting Vehicles without needing more cash from Congress.

;

;If Ukraine is dependent on its allies to provide it with most of the materiel it needs to fight the war, it must take the blame for being slow to recruit more soldiers. The average age of Ukraine's troops serving on the frontline is 43. Although morale, according to reports, remains generally high, many of them are exhausted and need rotating.

;

;With the promise of pay beyond the dreams of many families in poor parts of the country, Russia has little difficulty recruiting contract soldiers. Mr Muzyka reckons that there is a steady flow of about 30,000 fresh soldiers to the front each month—enough to sustain for the foreseeable future the “meat attacks” that were used day after day in the battle for Avdviika. In the aftermath of its sham presidential election, Russia's defence minister, Sergei Shoigu, announced on March 20th the formation of two new armies, which will require an additional 300,000-400,000 soldiers.

;

;Despite political reluctance, it is clear that Ukraine must mobilise on a much wider scale than permitted under current law, which does not allow conscription of anyone below the age of 27. In December Ukraine's then-commander-in-chief, Valery Zaluzhny, wanted to recruit a further 400,000 soldiers but, demanding more details, Mr Zelensky refused to sign a bill that would have lowered the age of enlistment to 25.

;

;The mobilisation bill that is currently going through parliament has been subject to thousands of amendments, including requirements that soldiers must be rotated every six months and allowed to leave the army after three years' service. It may now be passed in early April. The new recruits will need to be processed and trained, however, which will take several months. Meanwhile, the new commander-in-chief, Oleksandr Syrsky, is conducting an audit to see why from a 900,000-strong army only 300,000 soldiers have actually seen combat.

;

;Nor does Mr Zelensky have much excuse for the delays in constructing defensive fortifications, particularly after the Russians showed in the summer that defenders in this war have the upper hand when operating from well-prepared lines. It was not until November that the president announced the start of major construction employing both engineering troops and civilian contractors. An integrated defence system, including anti-tank ditches, “dragon's teeth” obstacles, minefields, firing points and earthworks to provide protection for infantry, is only now slowly taking shape. For now at least, says Mr Muzyka, a stalemate looks like the best-case scenario for Ukraine.  ;■;

;;N;;ot many; politicians last more than a few years in charge. Short tenures give rise to temptation: to borrow money now and leave the next lot to foot the bill. Economists call this “deficit bias”, the fiscal equivalent of St Augustine's prayer: “Lord, make me chaste. But not yet.”

;

;To tackle this problem Britain has fiscal rules, self-imposed restrictions on government borrowing. The problem is that politicians keep changing them, or make them too easy to game. On March 19th ;Rachel Reeves;, the shadow chancellor of the exchequer, announced plans for Labour's fiscal rules if they win the next election. They would represent an improvement, not a fix.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Start with stability, where Britain has a particular problem. Between 1997 and 2021 its fiscal rules have lasted, on average, for under four years, about the lifespan of a gerbil. Fiscal rules gain power with age: bond markets take ever-changing promises less seriously, which means higher borrowing costs. So it is somewhat welcome that Ms Reeves plans mostly to retain the existing rules. But only somewhat.

;

;She opted to preserve wholesale the main rule, which requires that the ratio of government debt to ;GDP; falls in the fifth year of the five-year forecast from the Office for Budget Responsibility (;OBR;), a watchdog that marks the Treasury's sums. This rule has several flaws. One is that five-year forecasts are imperfect. The ;OBR;'s past growth projections have missed the mark by 0.9 percentage points on average.

;

;The rule ignores borrowing between the first and fourth years of the forecast period; governments can ratchet debt up freely before then. Once a year has passed, the clock resets and another five-year period begins; the government is reportedly eyeing fresh giveaways after a new fiscal year starts on April 6th. Long time horizons mean that chancellors can comply with the rule by pencilling in future restraint that they have little intention of actually showing. Current spending plans imply implausibly sharp cuts to police, the courts and local government by 2028-29.

;

;Making the debt rule bind over three years, not five, would help. ;OBR ;growth estimates have been a third more accurate over that shorter period. And it is harder for voters to ignore plans for spending cuts that are only a year or two away.

;

;Ms Reeves does intend to tweak Britain's second fiscal rule. She plans to move from capping yearly government borrowing at 3% of ;GDP; five years out to a rule that ensures a balanced budget for day-to-day spending on things like welfare but excludes borrowing to invest on infrastructure and the like. That is sensible: separating them mutes incentives to raid capital budgets to plug gaps in current spending (even if the boundary between the two is not completely clear-cut).

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The shadow chancellor also announced plans to put more emphasis on public sector net worth (;PSNW;), a measure of the government's full balance-sheet. Debt-to-;GDP ;measures focus on governments' liabilities and ignore their assets. That lets chancellors flatter the public finances by flogging state-owned property. Ditching debt-to-;GDP ;targets altogether in favour of ;PSNW ;would be a mistake, since the concept is tricky to measure, but one proposal worth exploring would be to make the impact of government policy on ;PSNW; a yardstick. That would end up incorporating well-executed investments into calculations of fiscal sustainability while penalising money-wasting failures.

;

;Ms Reeves has also promised to mandate that the ;OBR ;forecasts all big tax-and-spend announcements, to prevent the watchdog from being sidelined as it was when ;Liz Truss; and Kwarti Kwarteng concocted their disastrous “mini-budget” in 2022. More significant would be to ensure those forecasts are realistic. The ;OBR;'s; ;forecast is bound to take the government's stated intentions at face value. This protects the watchdog's independence, by ensuring it is not seen to make political judgments, but strains its credibility. Since 2011 successive chancellors have pledged to raise fuel duty, for example; none has done so, yet the ;OBR; must pretend they will.

;

;The watchdog; ;does now estimate a more realistic secondary scenario in which fuel duty stays frozen (this cuts the current fiscal headroom the government has to cut taxes or increase spending by half). It could extend this approach—for instance, by constructing scenarios that explicitly embed governments' past tendency to underestimate its future borrowing, or that show how longer-term spending cuts might actually affect specific departments.

;

;There is no perfect set of fiscal rules. Elected governments need leeway to borrow. Over-rigid limits cause problems: Germany faced a ;budget crisis; last year, after a ruling by the country's constitutional court limited the government's room for borrowing. Just resisting the urge to fiddle with them would be a step forward. ;■;
